script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, I’ve got a question that’s been nagging at me. What if I told you there’s something most people completely miss in the Creation story—something that changes how we see ourselves and our relationship with God? It’s right there in Genesis 1, but it’s so easy to gloss over.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Oh, I’m intrigued, David! I think I know where you’re going with this. There’s a detail in those verses that shifts everything when you notice it. Let’s dive in and uncover what’s hidden in plain sight.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Perfect. Let’s start with the big picture. When we read Genesis 1:26-27, Moses 2:26-27, and Abraham 4:26-27, we hear that we’re created in God’s image. But what does that really mean to ancient Israel, to Christ, and to us today?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a powerful question. From ancient Israel’s perspective, being made in God’s image meant they were set apart, a reflection of divine order in a chaotic world. For Christ, it points to His role as the perfect image of the Father, showing us the way. And for us in the modern restoration, it’s a reminder of our divine potential to become like Him.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Wait, that’s fascinating. So there’s this thread of divine identity running through time. Can we trace that idea across different dispensations? Like, how does this ‘image of God’ concept show up beyond just the Creation?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely, let’s follow that pattern. In the Creation accounts, we start with Genesis 1:26, ‘And God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness.’ Then, think about Moses in the Pearl of Great Price, where the same language reinforces our divine blueprint. Fast forward to the Doctrine and Covenants, like in 101:32-34, where the Lord promises to reveal all things about the earth and His creations—tying us back to that original purpose.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love how that connects! It’s like a golden thread from the beginning of time to the latter days. But let’s zoom in—how does this pattern play out in something tangible, like a symbol or theme across these accounts?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here’s where it gets powerful. Notice the theme of light in the Creation. In Genesis 1:3, God says, ‘Let there be light,’ and it’s the first step to order. That light becomes a symbol of Christ Himself in John 8:12, where He declares, ‘I am the light of the world.’ And today, we’re called to reflect that light as His image-bearers, showing His love in our actions.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s remarkable! I never saw light as a connecting piece like that. It’s almost like every step of Creation is pointing us to Christ. But let’s ground this in history for a moment. What do we know about how ancient people understood the Creation story?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Great question. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, creation myths often involved chaos being tamed by a deity, much like we see in Genesis 1:2 where the earth was ‘without form, and void.’ But what’s unique in the Israelite account is the personal nature of God’s work—He’s not just a distant force, but a Creator who forms humanity in His likeness. Archaeological findings, like ancient texts from Mesopotamia, show that the idea of humans bearing a divine image was rare and radical for the time.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That really brings it to life. So, this wasn’t just a story to them—it was a revolutionary way of seeing themselves. Now, let’s circle back to that initial puzzle. What’s the piece most people miss in Genesis 1 that changes everything?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here’s the key, David. Most people read ‘created in His image’ as just a physical resemblance. But when you dig deeper, especially with Moses 2:26-27, it’s about our potential to reflect His character—His love, His creativity, His holiness. It’s not just who we are now, but who we’re meant to become.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s a game-changer. I’ve always thought of it as a static thing, not a journey. Are there other connections in these accounts that point to this bigger plan?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Oh, definitely. Look at Genesis 1:28, mirrored in Moses 2:28 and Abraham 4:28, where God commands Adam and Eve to ‘be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth.’ That’s not just about family—it’s about stewarding creation, reflecting God’s care. And it ties directly to the plan of salvation, where families are central to eternal progression.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’m seeing it now. It’s like every detail in the Creation is a breadcrumb leading to the eternal plan. What about marriage in Genesis 2:18-25? How does that fit into this divine image idea?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Notice this connection. In Genesis 2:18, God says, ‘It is not good that the man should be alone; I will make him an help meet for him.’ Marriage, as ordained in these verses and confirmed in modern revelation like ‘The Family: A Proclamation to the World,’ reflects the unity of God’s image—male and female together. It’s a partnership that mirrors divine completeness.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s beautiful. So, living out these roles in marriage and family is part of reflecting His image. How do we bring this into our lives today? What’s a practical way to apply this understanding?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here’s a thought. Knowing we’re created in God’s image can shape how we treat ourselves and others. Maybe it’s taking a moment each day to care for your body as a sacred gift, or seeing someone struggling and lifting them with kindness, recognizing their divine worth. It’s about living with purpose, reflecting His light in small, intentional ways.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love that. It’s so actionable. Sarah, this has been eye-opening—seeing the Creation not just as a past event, but as a living invitation to become more like Him. What’s one thing you’d invite our listeners to do with what we’ve discussed?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’d invite everyone to read Genesis 1:26-27 this week and ponder what being made in God’s image means to you personally. Write down one way you can reflect His character—whether it’s through kindness, creativity, or stewardship—and act on it. You’ll feel closer to Him as you do.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s a powerful challenge. Thank you, Sarah, for uncovering these profound connections with us. We’ll see you all next time on the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App.
